translated: Sutra of the Wise and Foolish, Scroll 17
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Chapter 16: Mindfulness, MindfulnessğŸ”½Mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation,
fully and accurately contemplating,ğŸ”½from beginning to end, thoroughly understanding,
in accordance with the Buddha's teachings.
Mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation means inhalation is tranquility and exhalation is dispersion.
The practitioner should skillfully observe the two gates of immortality:
one is tranquility and inhalation, the other is contemplation of impurity.

Some practitioners only cultivate tranquility and inhalation or contemplation of impurity. Those who cultivate tranquility and inhalation contemplate and discern inhalation and exhalation. They know when the breath is long and also know when it is short, they know when the breath is warm and also know when it is cold.

If the mind is confused, start from one again, and from head to toe, discern and be aware. If it is confused again, start from one again. In this way, go through it many times, and you will know when the mind reaches. I can now control the breath.

If you want to make the breath come out from the left ear, it is not difficult according to your wish. Coming in from the left ear is also like this. Coming in and out from the right ear, or coming in and out from the nose, you can all do it according to your wish. Finally, turn the breath and let it come out from the top of the head. If you can do it according to your wish, you have accomplished the method of counting the breath. If you cannot do it, the skull will split open and you will die.
In this way, a practitioner may go through twelve years, some succeeding and some not succeeding.

Next, the practitioner contemplates the impurity, going to a deserted place outside the city to observe a dead person's corpse, discerning it carefully, thinking, What is the difference between this corpse and my body?
They returned to the monastery, either sitting on a bed or on a sitting mat, or sitting in the open, and contemplated within themselves:
Remembering the corpse in the cemetery exposed, my body is no different from it.
In this way, they passed twelve years, some attaining concentration and some not.
Therefore, it is said, mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation.

As for fully contemplating the truth, a person with concentrated mind skillfully observes and distinguishes the six aspects: counting, following, stopping, observing, returning, and purifying. Therefore, it is said, fully contemplating the truth.
As for thoroughly mastering from beginning to end, day and night one is diligent without being lax, and if one misses [a breath], one starts from one again.
This is thorough mastery, not being tainted by the six sense faculties and external defilements.
Therefore, it is said, thoroughly mastering from beginning to end.

As the Buddha said, the reason the TathÄgata left behind the twelve divisions of the canon and analyzed the essential meanings is for the sake of those who are born later and have not yet awakened. He removes their hopes and desires with his vast wisdom. Therefore, it is said, As the Buddha said.
This then illuminates the world, like the sun appearing when the clouds part,
Arising and ceasing, studying and contemplating, sitting and lying down, never forgetting.

This then illuminates the world is like the autumn moon without the five obstructions. Among the many stars, its light uniquely shines. This is also like this. One who attains the concentration of mindfulness of breathing, among the many practitioners, their majestic spirit uniquely manifests and their appearance is radiant and unmatched. Therefore, it is said, This then illuminates the world, like the sun appearing when the clouds part.

As for practicing mindfulness of arising and ceasing, by attaining the concentration of mindfulness of breathing, the body and mind become firm and unmoving, not obstructed by external delusions, and the mind is also like this, not following external objects to give rise to deluded thoughts. Therefore, it is said, practicing mindfulness of arising and ceasing.

As for sitting or lying without forgetting, the practitioner who has attained meditative concentration always contemplates, whether sitting or lying, constantly learning without letting go for even a moment. Therefore, it is said, sitting or lying without forgetting.
The bhiká¹£u establishes this thought: what is beneficial in the beginning is good in the end.
What is attained in the beginning must be superior, vowing not to see birth and death.

As for the bhiká¹£u establishes this thought, it means that the bhiká¹£u permanently rests the myriad thoughts, the mind does not run wild, the will is firmly grasped, the various faculties are properly restrained, the mind is always in concentration, not seeking other thoughts. Therefore, it is said, the bhiká¹£u establishes this thought.

The former benefit is better than the latter means that first one attains the dhyÄna concentration of counting the breath, and later one is able to transcend the stages and realize the fruit, surpassing the three realms, with all the bonds in the body completely extinguished without remainder, pure like true gold forever free from the slightest obscuration. Therefore, it is said, The former benefit is better than the latter.

The beginning attainment is necessarily superior to the end means that one has already perfected knowledge and elimination, and one's transformative influence has pervaded everywhere. One's own body is liberated, and one will no longer accept future forms. Therefore, it is said, The beginning attainment is necessarily superior to the end, and one vows not to witness birth and death.
If one sees where the body abides, the six sense bases are considered supreme.
With a still mind, always single-minded, one will naturally attain nirvÄá¹‡a.

If one sees where the body abides means that bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, and new practitioners, male and female lay followers, ká¹£atriyas, brahmins, elders, and householders of various clans, who uphold their resolve firmly and pursue the path without difficulty, therefore it is said, If one sees where the body abides.

The sixth is considered the best means of closing off the six sense faculties. The eyes, ears, nose, mouth, body, and mind - all the sense faculties become clear and undisturbed, guarding the six sense faculties and not accepting any views. Therefore, it is said, The sixth is considered the best.

Always calming the mind and unifying the intention means that the practitioner counts the inhalations and exhalations, observing the pores, distinguishing each one without error, just as a person with clear eyes sees their own reflection in a bright mirror. Therefore, it is said, Always calming the mind and unifying the intention.

Then one can attain nirvana by oneself means severing the flow of afflictions and permanently leaving worldly affairs, then attaining nirvana, unmoving and unchanging, no longer coming and going or attached to the various realms. Therefore, it is said, Then one can attain nirvana by oneself.
Having these various thoughts, always practicing with one's own body,
If it is not like this, one will never attain the practice of the mind.

Having these various thoughts, always establishing oneself in practice, like those who practice, day and night diligently and attentively, not confused or mistaken, advancing to seek the Way, like encountering a conflagration, protecting and saving the burning head, in the beginning, middle, and end of the night, also not neglecting or forgetting, therefore it is said, having these various thoughts, always establishing oneself in practice.

If it is not like this, one will never attain the practice of the mind, birth and death are long and far-reaching, also without beginning or end, understanding nirvana has already left the three realms past, future, and present, therefore it is said, if it is not like this, one will never attain the practice of the mind.
This is the practice of following the basis, thus crossing over love and toil,
If one can awaken the mind and thoughts, liberation and single-minded joy.

This refers to practitioners who follow their original practice. When beginners first enter the path, they may be taught mindfulness of breathing first, or they may be taught the contemplation of impurity first. It is necessary to observe the practitioner's mind and preferences. Therefore, it is said, This refers to practitioners who follow their original practice.
Thus, crossing over the toil of craving - craving is the root of illness, difficult to dig out and difficult to uproot.
Why is this?

Craving is difficult to dig out, craving is difficult to uproot. Moreover, this craving has gone through birth and death, pervading the three realms, increasing the four kinds of birth, and turning through the five paths. Who can be aware of it?
Only those with wisdom can be aware of the suffering and distress experienced in the three realms and five paths.
Therefore, it is said, Thus, crossing over the toil of craving.
If one can awaken the mind and thoughts, and attain the joy of liberation and single-mindedness,
Then one should immediately practice the Dharma equally, and thus cross over the stage of old age and death.

If one can be mindful while awake, that practitioner should focus the mind on clarity, not daring to sleep or be distracted. Accomplishing the fruits of the path depends on being awake, not on sleeping and attaining the path. Although one may be awake, if the mind is not focused, one will not accomplish the fruits of the path. When the mind is awake and the mind is focused, one will transcend the three realms and reach the realm of no remainder.
Therefore it is said, If one can be mindful while awake.

Liberation, single-minded joy means that practitioner who has attained concentration and is endowed with the myriad virtues. One who has not attained concentration cannot possess the myriad virtuous practices.

In the past, there was a licentious person whose mind was solely focused on the appearance of women, unable to let go of thoughts of awakening. He longed for the beauty of women, wanting to communicate and interact with them. In sleep and dreams, he imagined holding hands and strolling with them. At that time, his wife encountered an illness, and her bones and flesh wasted away, leaving only her skeleton.
At that time, there was always a knowledgeable monk who came and went in that household. His wife said to the monk:
I am now suffering from a serious illness, day and night I am weak and exhausted. I want to express my feelings, is it possible?
The monk said:
Just speak without distress. If there are hidden matters, I will conceal them and not let them be revealed.
The woman said:
My husband has a nature of excessive sexual desire. He harasses me day and night, not allowing me to eat or rest. Because of this, I became ill and fear I cannot save myself.
The monk said to the woman:
If your husband comes near you, then tell him this:
Is it proper for a srota-Äpanna to act like this?
Later, as she said, when her husband came near her, she immediately said:
Is it proper for a husband who is a srota-Äpanna to act like this?
When her husband heard his wife's words, he was very ashamed and thought to himself:
Am I not really a srota-Äpanna?
He then put aside his thoughts and in a secluded place contemplated and analyzed, attaining the fruits of saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin and anÄgÄmin.
Knowing he had attained the path, he no longer engaged with women.
The woman asked her husband:
Why do you now completely stop your lustful thoughts and not engage with me?
The husband told his wife:
I have indeed seen you, so how can I continue to come and go with you?
The wife said to her husband:
You say you have seen me, but what fault do I have?
I am always chaste and do not violate the rites for women. Why do you scold me to this extent?
The woman then gathered her five relatives and told them:

Now my husband's views are distant and cold. He completely stops intimate feelings and no longer associates with me. He also scolds me, saying he has seen me. Now in front of the assembly, he can speak of it.
The husband said:
Stop!
I need to draw on evidence to clarify myself.
The husband returned home, painted a beautiful jar, filled it with excrement, tightly covered its mouth, perfumed it with fragrant flowers, returned to the assembly, and said to his wife:
Do you truly love me?
If you love me, you can embrace this jar as if it were my body.
The wife followed his words, embraced the jar, and played with it, never letting go of it.
The husband saw that his wife had already become attached to the jar, immediately broke the jar, and the foul stench overflowed, with maggots appearing. He then said to his wife:
Can you still embrace this broken jar now?
The wife replied:

I would rather die than be able to approach this broken jar. I would rather enter a fire pit, jump into deep water, or throw myself from a high mountain, with my head and feet in different places, than be able to approach this jar.
The husband told his wife:
What I said before was just seeing this very thing.
I observe your body to be more fragile than this vase. From head to toe, discerningly contemplating the thirty-six substances, what is there to crave?
At that time, he again spoke a verse, saying:
The hero enters concentration and observes the defilements arising from body and mind.
Seeing them, he gives rise to disgust, like a vase painted with colors.
Therefore it is said, The bliss of liberation and single-mindedness.

As for the timely and equal practice of the Dharma, a practitioner of cultivation relies on a good and virtuous friend, or is protected by the gods, and external evil does not enter. Seeking the Way is very easy and there is nothing to fear or find difficult.
It is like a person traveling far who becomes lost and abandons the great road to follow a small path. An alert person tells him:
This is not the right road. You can change your mind and repent and follow the right road.
At that time, the person who was lost on the road follows his instructions and returns to the great road, safely returning home.
The practitioner is also like this. Relying on a good and virtuous friend, they attain the right path. Therefore, it is said: The Dharma of timely and equal practice.

As for the stage of transcending old age and death, it is like a person traveling on a road with many dangers, perhaps encountering tigers, wolves, or bandits, or encountering treacherous and evil ghosts, or encountering dangerous roads that require them to walk sideways. Such difficulties are hundreds of thousands of times. Moreover, they may encounter a shortage of water and food. The person thinks to themselves:
If there is just one danger on the road, it is still difficult to pass through, let alone many dangers?
They then set their mind, day and night without rest, and are able to overcome those difficulties, return safely, and not lose their wealth and treasures.
The practitioner observes that the three realms are all burning, wishing to be far removed and seek the unconditioned path. Therefore, it is said: The stage of transcending old age and death.
The bhiká¹£u who awakens the mind should make it accord with this thought,
Completely abandoning birth and death, he is able to make an end to suffering.

As for the bhiká¹£u who contemplates with awakened mind, in the past there were merchants passing through a wilderness. Exhausted from the road, they slept all night. A group of thieves came together and wanted to rob them.
At that time, a spirit in the sky spoke to the merchants in verse from the sky, saying:ğŸ”½Who is awake and who is asleep?
Who is asleep and who is awake?
Who knows and who discriminates?
See the retribution as it accords with the meaning.
At that time, among the merchants there was an upÄsaka who was a disciple of the Buddha's five precepts. He replied, saying:
I am awake and I am asleep. I am asleep and I am awake.
I know and I discriminate. I want to know this meaning.
The spirit asked again, saying:ğŸ”½How is being awake the same as being asleep?
How is being asleep the same as being awake?
How is knowing the same as discriminating?
I want to hear this meaning.
At that time, the upÄsaka replied to the spirit, saying:
The eightfold noble path is expounded by the three Buddhas,
In that awakened dharma, I am asleep.
Those who are not awakened to the eightfold path are said by the three Buddhas,
In that sleeping and awakened dharma, I am awake.
This is what the deity said, I am awake, I am asleep, I am asleep, I am awake, I know, I discriminate, I wish to know this meaning.
The deity further said:
Excellent, being awake is sleep, excellent, being asleep is awake,
Excellent, knowing and discriminating, excellent, hearing this meaning.
At that time, the upÄsaka, having heard this meaning, immediately replied to the deity, saying:
I have been favored by the deity's peace and safety and have been able to return.
The deity, confused by the thieves, did not know where the merchants had set up camp, allowing the merchants to pass through the dangerous road.
Therefore it is said, The bhiká¹£us should be mindful with awakened minds.

One should cause it to be remembered means that the practitioner should hold the mind diligently, and whatever the mind wishes for will be accomplished without fail. Pure and free from defilement, not indulging in negligence, the body wears the robe of diligence, the mind harbors the light of wisdom, and the darkness of ignorance has no chance to appear. Therefore, it is said, One should cause it to be remembered.

Completely abandoning birth and death means that the practitioner further uses skillful means to sever the various bonds and attachments, abandoning the heavy, abandoning the light, peeling off the heavy, peeling off the light, striking the heavy, striking the light, and leaving behind birth, old age, sickness, and death. Therefore, it is said, Completely abandoning birth and death.

Causing the end of suffering means that in the present Dharma, one transcends the dharmas of ordinary beings, not attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle, attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a upon birth, attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice in the formless realm, and attaining ultimate parinirvÄá¹‡a without returning to saá¹ƒsÄra. Such a learner attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the present Dharma, abandoning these five kinds of parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Why is it so?
The Buddha's sutras and the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢gama say:
I now tell the bhiká¹£us that even a small part of birth is not allowed, not even for the time of a finger snap, let alone more.
Why is this?
The suffering of receiving a part of birth is due to this transmigration without escaping suffering.
Bhiká¹£us should contemplate it as if it were a latrine, even a small amount always stinks, let alone more.
Therefore, bhiká¹£us!
You should seek skillful means to cut off the part of receiving birth and permanently leave the three existences.
In this way, bhiká¹£us!
You should study like this, uproot the root of birth and do not let it proliferate.

The practicing people heard what the Buddha said, accepted the teachings, and in the present Dharma, uprooted the root of birth and did not receive it again. Therefore it is said, They are able to make an end of suffering.
Always listen to the subtle, and awaken your mind by yourself,
Those who are able to awaken are the wise, who have no fear of beginning and end.

Always listen to the subtle Dharma means that it is very difficult to encounter a person who expounds the Dharma, and it is also difficult to attain complete faculties. Meeting a sage or encountering a saint is only possible once in many eons. The World-Honored One said:

In the past, I accumulated practices for hundreds of thousands of eons before I heard the Dharma. Although I was able to hear the Dharma, it is even more difficult to encounter the meaning of the Dharma.
He told the assembly that had come to listen with utmost concentration to the subtle Dharma. Therefore, it is said, Always listen to the subtle Dharma.
Awaken and understand one's own mind means that when the World-Honored One was in the world, he was surrounded by countless hundreds of thousands of people, who listened to his Dharma talks.
At that time, there was a person in the great assembly who was deeply asleep.
A bhiká¹£u told the sleeping bhiká¹£u:
Why don't you awaken and listen to the TathÄgata's Dharma talk?
You are still sleeping and disturbing the great assembly.
Why don't you observe the TathÄgata's subtle Dharma?
It is more delicious than nectar and removes people's myriad afflictions.
The man heard this and remained silent, not responding.
Therefore it is said: Awaken your own mind.

Those who are able to awaken are wise. This awakening is millions of times greater than heaven and earth. It cannot be compared with metaphors. Some practitioners are obscured by the five hindrances and six coverings, drowsy and attached to sleep. The gods support and often come to awaken them, watching over the mad elephant of life that tramples the seedlings of the three roots of goodness, and the blazing fire of impermanence burns the roots and sprouts of living beings.

The Honored One among Humans appeared today, illuminating the three realms everywhere without exception. The thieves of afflictions steal good wealth. Such myriad changes are innumerable, all due to not being awakened from sleep.
Therefore it is said: Those who are able to awaken are wise.

As for having no fear throughout beginningless cyclic existence, when a person is awake, the myriad evils cannot disturb them. Not only is the person practicing the Way considered wise when awake, even ordinary worldly people can accomplish various things through being awake. Sometimes laypeople lose their wealth in their sleep, and are harmed by enemies, creditors, thieves, or water and fire. Sometimes practitioners are drowsy and sleep, and when they should hear the Dharma, they do not hear it; when they should attain the fruits of the Way, they do not attain them; when they should recite and practice the roots of the path to awakening, they lose them all in their sleep.
Therefore it is said, having no fear throughout beginningless cyclic existence.
By means of the awakened mind, one attains accord, and day and night aspires to practice.
One should understand the essentials of the nectar, and cause all defilements to be exhausted.

As for attaining through awakening the mind, the practitioner contemplates and thinks, day and night praising the virtues of awakening, while those who are indolent also praise the essentials of sleep. Therefore, it is said, attaining through awakening the mind.

As for aspiring to practice day and night, the practitioner diligently exerts themselves, day and night without rest, not missing the sequence before, after, and in between. Therefore, it is said, aspiring to practice day and night.

As for understanding the essentials of immortality, the eightfold noble path is called immortality, and the cessation of nirvana is also called immortality. The practitioner studies the eightfold noble path and progresses towards nirvana, leaving behind the eight kinds of idle chatter and desires, tranquil, simple, unconditioned, and uncontrived. Therefore, it is said, understanding the essentials of immortality.
As for causing all taints to be exhausted, what does the meaning of taint refer to?
For what reason is it called the meaning of taint?
The answer is:

The meaning of abiding is the meaning of leakage, the meaning of soaking is the meaning of leakage, the meaning of dripping is the meaning of leakage, the meaning of increasing is the meaning of leakage, the meaning of not being held by non-humans is the meaning of leakage.
As for abiding being the meaning of leakage, by what is the abiding of beings in the desire realm controlled?
Answer:
By leakage.
By what is the abiding of beings in the form and formless realms controlled?
Answer:
By leakage.
Therefore, abiding is said to be the meaning of leakage.
How is soaking the meaning of leakage?
Answer:
Just as grains sprout when soaked in water,
so it is with beings. They are soaked in the water of the three existences, and the sprouts of their past karmic bonds grow. This is called soaking being the meaning of leakage.

As for dripping being the meaning of leakage, it is like a spring leaking from a roof, a deep pool, a ditch, or a mother's heavy love naturally overflowing. This is called dripping being the meaning of leakage.

As for the meaning of 'outflows' as 'superiority', it is like the mutual respect among humans. The superior and inferior, the noble and humble each have their place. Above there is a wise ruler, and below the people cannot go east and west as they please. This class of sentient beings is also like this. They are controlled by afflictions and cannot escape the three realms, the four forms of birth, or the five destinies. This is called the meaning of 'outflows' as 'superiority'.

As for the meaning of 'outflows' as 'being possessed by non-humans', it is like a person being possessed by a non-human, speaking wildly, avoiding what should be avoided, leaving what should be left, holding what should be held, and grasping what cannot be grasped.

This class of sentient beings is also like this. They are possessed by the non-human of afflictions and speak wildly. Therefore, it is said that the meaning of 'outflows' is 'being possessed by non-humans'.

One who can sever these defilements is the sole honored one among humans and gods. Whatever one thinks in one's mind will surely be accomplished without difficulty, and one will attain the knowledge of ending, uproot the foundation of suffering, reach the ultimate state, not experience future existence, and attain the acceptance of non-arising.
Therefore, it is said, One who can sever these defilements.
When a person attains true benefit, they come to take refuge in the Buddha.
Therefore, day and night, one should single-mindedly think of the Buddha.

As for attaining true benefit in the world, it refers to the benefits of elephants, horses, carriages, the wealth of a country, wives, children, gold, silver, and precious treasures such as agate, carnelian, crystal, lapis lazuli, coral, amber, and so on. Although these are said to be true benefits, they are not genuine benefits. They deceive worldly people and lead to disputes, causing the loss of countries and the destruction of families. One cannot avoid the hells, hungry ghosts, and animal realms. Only by entrusting one's life and taking refuge in the TathÄgata can one escape the difficulties of the hells and animal realms.

Those who take refuge in the Buddha cut off existence, attain the desire for non-existence, and attain realization by skipping stages, following the practices of the three vehicles and each attaining their wishes, if reborn in the heavens or among humans they receive natural blessings.

If one first gives rise to the intention and aspires to the Buddha's path, one further attains the four foundations of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the eightfold noble path. These are called the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
Therefore it is said, People attain good benefits.
Question:
Why only speak of people attaining fruition and not of devas, nÄgas, asuras, yaká¹£as, and ghosts?
Answer:

The human realm is the most honored and wonderful of all destinies. With a focused mind, one can immediately cut off defilements, end bonds, and attain realization by skipping stages. The human realm is capable of receiving the teachings of the noble path, so it speaks of people.
As for those who take refuge in the Buddha, what is meant by taking refuge?
Why is it said to take refuge?
Answer:
The meaning of refuge is to save and protect.
Moreover, the meaning of refuge is fearlessness and deliverance from difficulties.
Therefore, it is said, From now on, I take refuge in the Buddha.

Therefore, day and night, one should single-mindedly think of the Buddha. The mind of a person wanders in myriad ways, creating immeasurable actions in the blink of an eye. Day and night, thoughts are unceasing. Within this, one should pull oneself out and turn the mind towards goodness, single-mindedly thinking of the Buddha without any other thoughts. Therefore, one should single-mindedly think of the Buddha day and night.
When a person obtains good benefits, they should take refuge in the Dharma.
Therefore, day and night, one should single-mindedly think of the Dharma.
What is called the Dharma is the extinction of nirvana. For those who have fear, it leads to the unconditioned;
For those who have no fear, what difficulty is there in attaining the Way?

As for conditioned phenomena, they are seen to be oppressed by birth, old age, sickness, and death. In the extinction of nirvana, there is no birth, old age, sickness, or death. Therefore, it is said, When a person obtains good benefits, they should take refuge in the Dharma.

As for those who think of the Dharma day and night with a single mind, as for the Dharma, it brings blessings in the present and removes all afflictions and troubles. It is practiced by the wise and not by the foolish. Therefore, it is said, Those who think of the Dharma day and night with a single mind.
When a person obtains good benefits, they should take refuge in the Sangha.
Therefore, they should think of the Sangha day and night with a single mind.
As for those who obtain good benefits and take refuge in the Sangha, it is asked:
The meaning of taking refuge is to be fearless. In the great assembly, there are those who are terrified. Why is it said to take refuge in the Sangha?
The answer is:
There may be a great assembly that has already escaped the five difficulties and is no longer afraid.
What are the five difficulties?
First, the difficulty of being born, second, the difficulty of aging, third, the difficulty of illness, fourth, the difficulty of death, and fifth, the difficulty of not enjoying the assembly.
Free from these five difficulties, one can then take refuge in oneself.
What is meant by the assembly?
The various heterodox assemblies, naked ascetics, from one to ten and even countless, the noble assembly of the TathÄgata is the most supreme among all assemblies.
Therefore it is said, when a person obtains good benefits, they can take refuge in the assembly themselves. Therefore, day and night, they should single-mindedly think of the assembly.
Those who can know and realize for themselves are the disciples of Gautama.
Day and night, they should think of this and single-mindedly take refuge in the Buddha.

As for those who can know and realize for themselves, initially taking refuge in the Dharma is not definite in meaning. Now, thinking of the Buddha is called definite, firmly taking refuge in the Buddha without being able to move. Therefore it is said, those who can know and realize for themselves.

Disciples of Gautama - the Tathagata came from the Gautama clan. Observing future events, he spoke this meaning. In the future, there will be beings born without parents, suddenly appearing in a noble and respected position, boasting in the world. The Tathagata wished to stop their slander, so he said disciples of Gautama.

Day and night, one should think of this, single-mindedly thinking of the Buddha. Those who single-mindedly think of the Buddha, evil demons and hordes dare not encroach upon them. Therefore, it is said, Day and night, one should think of this Buddha, single-mindedly thinking of the Dharma.
Those who are well-awakened and self-awakened are disciples of Gautama.
Day and night, one should think of this, single-mindedly thinking of the Dharma.
Those who are well-awakened and self-awakened - the Buddha told the bhikshus:
You should observe and contemplate the essentials of the Dharma, and remove confused thoughts.ğŸ”½Those who are well-awakened and self-awakened - the Buddha told the bhikshus:
Therefore it is said, Those who are well-awakened and self-awakened are the disciples of Gautama. Day and night they should contemplate this, single-mindedly contemplating the Dharma.
Those who are well-awakened and self-awakened are the disciples of Gautama.
Day and night they should contemplate this, single-mindedly contemplating the Saá¹…gha.
The Buddha told the great assembly:
You all see the entire assembly, seeing with wisdom, not without wisdom, observing with insight, not without insight, and also know the purity and impurity of my assembly.
Therefore it is said, Those who are well-awakened and self-awakened are the disciples of Gautama. Day and night they should contemplate this, single-mindedly contemplating the Saá¹…gha.
Contemplating the body, impermanence, precepts, generosity and virtue,
heaven, mindfulness of breathing, and death, day and night they should contemplate this.

That practitioner, upholding the precepts completely, pure and undefiled, like a vajra that cannot be destroyed, like Mount Sumeru that cannot be moved, therefore it is said, Contemplate the body, contemplate impermanence, contemplate the virtues of precepts and giving, contemplate heaven, mindfulness of breathing, and death, day and night, always contemplate these.
What is meant by contemplating giving? Giving is of two kinds:
Material giving and giving of afflictions.
Giving of afflictions is called ultimate, giving without regret.
Material giving is not ultimate giving, giving that is regretted after giving.
Therefore it is said to contemplate giving.

What is meant by contemplating heaven?
